What it says is: I urge that supplications, prayers, intercessions, and thanksgivings be made for all people, for kings and all who are in high positions, that we may lead a peaceful and quiet life, godly and dignified in every way.

The bible often places an emphasis on the importance of strong leadership. I don't see how telling the populace to remember to pray to those who lead would be contrary to its message. It doesn't even say we should do these various things *more to leaders, and instead of advocating for leaders to be accepted into position without question, 1 Timothy gives at least 10-11 requirements for the status of overseer.

> The bible often places an emphasis on the importance of strong leadership.

No, church and national tradition is what emphasizes "strong leadership" and those are two of the biggest enemies to believers in every part of the bible. If you are truly right, then why do you need the power to stomp out opposition? It wouldn't be a threat to you! Nearly every major conflict in the whole bible is caused by those in power, we have Pharaoh, then the Canaanites and the evil kings of Israel and Judah (and even the good ones didn't have it together), then the Babylonians, then the Pharisees and the Roman government, and a whole bunch of other stuff. They are even responsible for the crucifixion. It's always the same pattern: someone in power feels threatened by Christians and tries to execute the final solution. Even writers who try to portray Jewish kings as favorably as possible admit that having one at all was the result of idolatrous people literally demanding it (1 Samuel 8). Humans are tribal animals, and both wanting to attain power and dominion for yourself and idolizing those above you are some of the most basic social instincts. This is why we see people worshiping celebrities and politicians and even popular people in their own circle to the point of absurdity. This is why they value conformity above all else and reflexively coerce offenders back into line. But the flesh and the spirit are opposed to one another!

> It doesn't even say we should do these various things *more to leaders

This verse most definitely implies it. If the writer does not set aside leaders as special then why the need to elaborate specifically on them so much?

> instead of advocating for leaders to be accepted into position without question, 1 Timothy gives at least 10-11 requirements for the status of overseer.

Yes, to make sure leaders are approved of by the author of 1 Timothy. He wouldn't want his own system to backfire on him by placing people he doesn't like in power! Of course the simple solution to avoid all this mess is to just follow Jesus's advice in Matthew 23.

That makes the biblically-strong-leader = tyrant? How does that begin to follow?

and in a personal letter to a friend?

It would be inaccurate to just call Timothy "a friend." Timothy was a disciple, the son of a Jewish woman and Greek man, met by Paul in Acts, whom he references in Timothy. Timothy was well spoken of by the brothers at Lystra and Iconium, and was specifically said to be taken with Paul as Acts continues, leading to a couple of undesigned coincidences.

Wouldn't it make like a LOT more sense to do that in a public letter?

Should Paul have attempted to make an announcement rather than instruct a letter to his diciple? That would depend on if it would have been more efficient to his time, and publicised. Obviously, we know it was successful on both fronts.

And one that actually matches his writing style and doesn't use words that didn't exist until decades after his death? It's pretty obvious that it's not legit.

Neat, it would be nice to know your definite proof that he used words that didn't exist until decades after his death.

Also consider that in ancient times, it wasn't considered forgery to write in someone's name if it was deemed "good", and combined with the lack of information in those days it was quite easy to get away with it.

No, adding to the Word of God wasn't exactly praised.

1 Timothy very specifically attacks schools of thought which did not surface until after Paul's death, specifically those which relied heavily on his authentic letters, and directly contradicts Paul and early Christianity many times.

Great, what are those schools of thought that he couldn't have known about, and what are those contradictions.

Most of what people think the bible says is actually what their favorite televangelist told them it says. For example I bet you didn't know that:

christian agrees with popular biblical interpretation, therefore hasn't read bible

The bible says it's been corrupted by scribes (Jeremiah 8:8)

"Copyists" isn't synonymous with "scribe." These were interpreters and, in their interpretations, essentially false teachers, a common idea in the bible.

Jesus is perfectly okay with not marrying and even castrating yourself (Matthew 19:12)

...Yeah?

God never actually commanded sacrifices (Jeremiah 7:21-23 which is deliberately mistranslated in most english bibles to conceal this)

Also concealed or deliberately mistranslated in Leviticus, Genesis, Hebrews...?

Israel and Judah were never supposed to have a king (1 Samuel 8)

Huh? Deuteronomy 17:14-15 Even without the context of Deuteronomy, this is read as a very situational passage. Going into a passage, especially a situational one, with the intent to prove a point rather than find the original idea of the passage isn't going to be helpful.

Joseph is the biological father of Jesus. All the old testament prophecies clearly describe the messiah as the seed of Abraham and David, and it is not Mary who is descended from them because all the genealogies show Joseph's family tree. Luke 1-2 and Matthew 1:18-24 are judged to be later additions to the original text.

It's ironic. Though I'm accussed of only listening to my favorite televangelists, you made a claim from biblical critics and simply wrote "are judged" as though it's the consensus of biblical scholars.

The "Old Testament" is still in effect, as God never changes. Jesus did not change it, rather he declared that the Jews had it wrong the entire time and called them out on the spot, before the resurrection when the old law was supposedly annulled. They had changed it and twisted it. For example we can eat literal pork not because of the "New Testament" but because what goes into a mouth does not make someone unclean, but what comes out of it, and that has always been and always will be. All the law is derived from the golden rule which governs us, and if something doesn't it's either being misunderstood or it was altered by humans. Our idea of dispensationalism seems to stem from a misunderstanding on Paul's part in his letter to the Galatians, if that is what he truly wrote.

That just sounds like a stretch. Where did he declare the Jews had it wrong the entire time and called them out on the spot?

Literally the first one is "don't be female". This is hardly so important unless we understand that second-century heresies became associated with women at some point. Prior to that no such teaching existed at all, let alone so vital

Considering various teachings of Jesus being new, why would teachings upon an almost completely new church be such an outrageous idea?

Let's also be clear that the next statement literally says people who don't have children can't be saved.

Yes, "literally" in the sense of removing context to prove a point.

We know:

  1. Directly prior to the verse: For Adam was formed first, then Eve; and Adam was not deceived, but the woman was deceived and became a transgressor.

  2. This is further mentioned in 1 Timothy 5:14-15: So I would have younger widows marry, bear children, manage their households, and give the adversary no occasion for slander. For some have already strayed after Satan.

  3. In 1 Timothy 4:16: Watch your life and doctrine closely. Persevere in them, because if you do, you will save (sozo) both yourself and your hearers. When in the context of it's own book, it certaintly does give more of a case to spiritual preservation rather than the "not saving by faith" idea, the idea that contradicts the church in the forgery "decades after his death."

This criterion is basic "be a good person" stuff. Pretty much no one will disagree with that so there's not much to discuss here.

It's almost as though it's to prevent the corruption of those who teach what they do not do, otherwise the teachers of the law in Jesus' time.

The next qualification is that you must be married with children, and also that you must rule your family members. Again, this paints not doing so in a negative light, the opposite of Paul's view for at least the former point, but very much in line with Roman culture. If we are to follow this rule then we must forsake Jesus, because he did not have a spouse or children. And also Paul himself, of which the same is true, and in that case he is ironically not qualified to be setting this rule in the first place!

Let's actually read what Paul said about marriage:

Now concerning the matters about which you wrote: “It is good for a man not to have sexual relations with a woman.” 2 But because of the temptation to sexual immorality, each man should have his own wife and each woman her own husband.

To the unmarried and the widows I say that it is good for them to remain single, as I am. 9 But if they cannot exercise self-control, they should marry. For it is better to marry than to burn with passion.

Again, being accused of not reading the bible... though the idea that Paul wanted to keep church leaders from sexual immorality isn't even taken into consideration.

Paul became an apostle right after converting from brutally murdering Christians. This hardly sounds like something he'd say.

...Do you think Paul wanted prior Christian-murders to be leaders of churches, and assumed they would be as godly as he is?

This is one of the most concerning ones. The gist of it is "you must be doing what the world likes". This contradicts the countless promises that you will instead be hated and persecuted.

Considering basically every verse prior in this chapter, the consensus is that Paul speaks that they should be men seen with a noble and godly character even by outsiders, as a man who is not known as a devout Christian to those around him (at this time) has a much higher chance of weakness in the faith, therefore weakness towards corruption.

Finally, we have the fact that we are specifically warned not to consider anyone on earth teacher or father, which was probably a statement directed at the Jewish orthodoxy, to which 1 Timothy promotes a similar system.

Entire context and verse:

Then Jesus said to the crowds and to his disciples, “The scribes and the Pharisees sit on Moses' seat, so do and observe whatever they tell you, but not the works they do. For they preach, but do not practice. They tie up heavy burdens, hard to bear, and lay them on people's shoulders, but they themselves are not willing to move them with their finger. They do all their deeds to be seen by others. For they make their phylacteries broad and their fringes long, and they love the place of honor at feasts and the best seats in the synagogues and greetings in the marketplaces and being called rabbi by others. But you are not to be called rabbi, for you have one teacher, and you are all brothers. And call no man your father on earth, for you have one Father, who is in heaven. Neither be called instructors, for you have one instructor, the Christ. The greatest among you shall be your servant. Whoever exalts himself will be humbled, and whoever humbles himself will be exalted."

While taking this section out of context, I wonder if "call no man your father/instructor was taken literally as well... When we look at this scripture without a bias, and entirely in context, we find that these were all titles used to exalt instructors, and have a final consensus that we we should not exalt ourselves as the Pharisees were.

The entire chapter. You've been fooled yet again, this time into thinking that the bible is just a collection of a bunch of contextless sentences called verses.

Believe it or not, I understand the meaning of context. It also doesn't seem wise to read a whole chapter, see no stance against the allied argument, then decide the opposing argument must be true because they said "It's the whole chapter!"

1: First of all, then, I urge that supplications, prayers, intercessions, and thanksgivings be made for all people, 

2: for kings and all who are in high positions, that we may lead a peaceful and quiet life, godly and dignified in every way. 

3: This is good, and it is pleasing in the sight of God our Savior, 

4: who desires all people to be saved and to come to the knowledge of the truth.

1: First of all, then, I urge that supplications, prayers, intercessions, and thanksgivings be made for all people,

2: for kings and all who are in high positions, that we may lead a peaceful and quiet life, godly and dignified in every way.

3: This is good, and it is pleasing in the sight of God our Savior,

4: who desires all people to be saved and to come to the knowledge of the truth.
